liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NSW police has announced an operation which will co-ordinate the reponse to demonstrations and events relating to the Hamas attack. NSW Acting Commissioner David Hudson says Operation Shelter will capture all intelligence available to community sentinment, potential protest activity and potential demonstrations. "This is not ideal and that we have to take the steps to co-ordinate our activity across the state," he said. "There has been a fair bit of activity over the past few days which we believe will continue into the foreseeable future. "I think it is incumbent upon us to stand up to this standalone operation to co-ordinate activities not just within the city region but also across the broader state of New South Wales." Acting Commissioner Hudson says the intent of the operation is to "ensure community safety". "We will take any steps to ensure that," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW police announces Operation Shelter to 'ensure community safety'

children.content: (ABC News)
NSW police has announced an operation which will co-ordinate the reponse to demonstrations and events relating to the Hamas attack.
NSW Acting Commissioner David Hudson says Operation Shelter will capture all intelligence available to community sentinment, potential protest activity and potential demonstrations.
"This is not ideal and that we have to take the steps to co-ordinate our activity across the state," he said.
"There has been a fair bit of activity over the past few days which we believe will continue into the foreseeable future.
"I think it is incumbent upon us to stand up to this standalone operation to co-ordinate activities not just within the city region but also across the broader state of New South Wales."
Acting Commissioner Hudson says the intent of the operation is to "ensure community safety".
"We will take any steps to ensure that," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are growing concerns for the lives of women and children in Gaza, with the Red Crescent warning the situation was catastrophic. Palestinian Red Crescent Society spokesperson Nebal Farsakh said Israel’s bombardment was taking a huge toll in Gaza. "We have dealt with around 300 fatalities as well as 1,200 injuries," she said. "Those are our teams who were able to deal with, while according to the Ministry of Health, around 900 Palestinians lost their lives among those 240 children and many are women." She also said air strikes and bombardments were taking place without enough warning for the residents to be evacuated in time. "We ourselves, our medical teams on many occasions it has happened, when we were evacuating families due to air strikes, the same second when we were in the building trying to evacuate people, another Israeli air strike hit the location and thank God by miracle, our team could save their lives,” she said. "The situation is dangerous, our team are working under very dangerous conditions due to the escalation and the continued bombardment in every single part of Gaza." She warned around 200,000 Palestinians have now been displaced and they are lacking basic humanitarian needs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Red Crescent says Israeli air strikes are hitting as workers evacuate families

mediaThumbnail.caption: Nebal Farsakh from Palestinian Red Crescent Society has raised concerns the city will run out of fuel and electricity in five days while hospitals struggle with lack of medical supplies.

children.content: There are growing concerns for the lives of women and children in Gaza, with the
Red Crescent
warning the situation was catastrophic.
Palestinian Red Crescent Society spokesperson
Nebal Farsakh
said Israel’s bombardment was taking a huge toll in Gaza.
"We have dealt with around 300 fatalities as well as 1,200 injuries," she said.
"Those are our teams who were able to deal with, while according to the Ministry of Health, around 900 Palestinians lost their lives among those 240 children and many are women."
She also said air strikes and bombardments were taking place without enough warning for the residents to be evacuated in time.

"We ourselves, our medical teams on many occasions it has happened, when we were evacuating families due to air strikes, the same second when we were in the building trying to evacuate people, another Israeli air strike hit the location and thank God by miracle, our team could save their lives,” she said.
"The situation is dangerous, our team are working under very dangerous conditions due to the escalation and the continued bombardment in every single part of Gaza."
She warned around 200,000 Palestinians have now been displaced and they are lacking basic humanitarian needs.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tim Callanan Representatives of the Australian Jewish and Palestinian communities have condemned anti-Semitic chants reported to have been shouted at pro-Palestinian demonstrations this week. Rallies were held in Sydney and Melbourne over the last two nights in support of Palestinians. The president of the Zionist Federation of Australia, Jeremy Leibler, said some of the slogans being chanted at the Sydney demonstration were unacceptable. "I'm terrified when I see these marches through the city that are not holding candles and calling for peace as we see from rallies in the Jewish community when things have flared up in the Middle East," he told ABC Radio Melbourne. "What we're seeing is violent protests." Mr Leibler said the response from Australian political leaders so far had been heartening. "I think we've had strong, very principled support – bipartisan support – both from the prime minister, from [opposition leader] Peter Dutton, and both at the state leadership levels as well," he said. "So there should be. As there was after 9/11." President of the Palestine Advocacy Network, Nasser Mashni, said he was disappointed by some of the language used at the pro-Palestinian demonstrations. "It's entirely unacceptable. There is no room in our movement for anti-Semitism, any level of racism, Islamophobia, whatever," he said. "Our struggle is an anti-colonial struggle for self-determination for all peoples in the holy land." However, he said the move to project the Israeli flag on the Sydney Opera House was hurtful for Australians with a Palestinian background. "I'm Australian too, why don't my children matter? When the [Sydney] Opera House is lit up in the Israeli flag there was an opportunity for Australia to have a moment of bringing together all peoples to say all children matter," he said. "Both the flags could have been there." Meanwhile, Victoria Police is investigating reports of anti-Semitic threats made in South Yarra yesterday. Police said the occupants of a car threatened a man on Toorak Road about 4pm yesterday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Entirely unacceptable': Australian Jewish, Palestinian communities condemn anti-Semitic chants

children.content: Reporting by
Tim Callanan
Representatives of the Australian Jewish and Palestinian communities have condemned anti-Semitic chants reported to have been shouted at pro-Palestinian demonstrations this week.
Rallies were held in Sydney and Melbourne over the last two nights in support of Palestinians.
The president of the
Zionist Federation of Australia
, Jeremy Leibler, said some of the slogans being chanted at the Sydney demonstration were unacceptable.

"I'm terrified when I see these marches through the city that are not holding candles and calling for peace as we see from rallies in the Jewish community when things have flared up in the Middle East," he told ABC Radio Melbourne.
"What we're seeing is violent protests."
Mr Leibler said the response from Australian political leaders so far had been heartening.

"I think we've had strong, very principled support – bipartisan support – both from the prime minister, from [opposition leader] Peter Dutton, and both at the state leadership levels as well," he said.
"So there should be. As there was after 9/11."
The demonstration at Sydney Opera House on Monday night.
(AAP: Dean Lewis)
President of the
Palestine Advocacy Network
, Nasser Mashni, said he was disappointed by some of the language used at the pro-Palestinian demonstrations.
"It's entirely unacceptable. There is no room in our movement for anti-Semitism, any level of racism, Islamophobia, whatever," he said.
"Our struggle is an anti-colonial struggle for self-determination for all peoples in the holy land."
However, he said the move to project the Israeli flag on the Sydney Opera House was hurtful for Australians with a Palestinian background.

"I'm Australian too, why don't my children matter? When the [Sydney] Opera House is lit up in the Israeli flag there was an opportunity for Australia to have a moment of bringing together all peoples to say all children matter," he said.
"Both the flags could have been there."
Meanwhile,
Victoria Police
is investigating reports of anti-Semitic threats made in South Yarra yesterday.
Police said the occupants of a car threatened a man on Toorak Road about 4pm yesterday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has spoken from Uluru with former MP Pat Farmer. Mr Farmer has just completed a 14,500km run throughout Australia in support of the Voice to Parliament. "He began on the south island when we farewelled him in Hobart in April and at that time, I pledged to join with him on this day in October,"Mr Albanese said. "He has provided an inspiration for Australians and what he has done is, in running 14,500km to ask his fellow Australians to just walk a few metres, walk into a polling booth and write Y-E-S on the ballot paper on the referendum." Mr Farmer said his mammoth run led to much time thinking of Indigenous history. "I am glad to be at this point in the world's time where we start to acknowledge Indigenous communities right around the world and the significance of that culture," Mr Farmer said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM speaks from Uluru with former MP Pat Farmer after 14,000km run

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese speaking from Uluru
(ABC News)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
has spoken from Uluru with former
MP Pat Farmer
Mr Farmer has just completed a
14,500km run throughout Australia in support of the Voice to Parliament
"He began on the south island when we farewelled him in Hobart in April and at that time, I pledged to join with him on this day in October,"Mr Albanese said.

"He has provided an inspiration for Australians and what he has done is, in running 14,500km to ask his fellow Australians to just walk a few metres, walk into a polling booth and write Y-E-S on the ballot paper on the referendum."
Mr Farmer said his mammoth run led to much time thinking of Indigenous history.
"I am glad to be at this point in the world's time where we start to acknowledge Indigenous communities right around the world and the significance of that culture," Mr Farmer said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In a couple of hours we'll hear Western Australian senator Patrick Dodson 's National Press Club address. Mr Dodson is also the special envoy for reconciliation and implementation of the Uluru Statement from the Heart. Previously, Mr Dodson was director of the Central and Kimberley Land Councils and a Commissioner in the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. His address will begin at 12:30pm AEDT. We'll be bringing you a live stream as well as blogging Mr Dodson's address.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Patrick Dodson to address National Press Club

children.content: Patrick Dodson will address the National Press Club later today.
(ABC News)

Western Australian senator Patrick Dodson

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney says she is "shocked" by comments made by the Opposition leader about late Northern Territory land rights advocate, Yunupiŋu. Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year Yunupiŋu died earlier this year aged 74, after a lifetime spent trying to better the outcomes of his Yolŋu people in north-east Arnhem Land. Yesterday, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton equated Yunupiŋu's work towards improving his Arnhem Land community with why a Voice to Parliament wasn't needed. "They've got a logging company, they've got a building company, they've got housing, they've got a functioning society … because of the leadership demonstrated by Yunupiŋu and others around him over the course of a long period, and that's what we want to see replicated elsewhere," he said. Mr Dutton's comments in Adelaide did not account for the fact that the East Arnhem local government area (LGA) remains one of the 10 most disadvantaged LGAs in Australia. In reaction, Ms Burney says she was "shocked at that statement". "Yunupiŋu spent his entire life fighting for his people, fighting for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people across this country and also advocating a Voice to Parliament," she said. "Quite frankly, Peter Dutton should apologise for taking the name of Yunupiŋu in vain. "The idea that there isn't disadvantage in north-east Arnhem Land is patently ridiculous. "Peter Dutton has no right at all to use the name of Yunupiŋu in that way." NOTE: Yunupiŋu's surname and image is used as per the wishes of his family.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Call for Peter Dutton to apologise over Yunupiŋu comments

children.content: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton (left) and Indigenous Australias Minister Linda Burney (right)
(ABC News)
Reporting by Matt Garrick
Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney
says she is "shocked" by comments made by the Opposition leader about late Northern Territory land rights advocate,
Yunupiŋu
Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year Yunupiŋu
died earlier this year aged 74
, after a lifetime spent trying to better the outcomes of his Yolŋu people in north-east Arnhem Land.
Yesterday,
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton
equated Yunupiŋu's work towards improving his Arnhem Land community with why a Voice to Parliament wasn't needed.

"They've got a logging company, they've got a building company, they've got housing, they've got a functioning society … because of the leadership demonstrated by Yunupiŋu and others around him over the course of a long period, and that's what we want to see replicated elsewhere," he said.
Mr Dutton's comments in Adelaide did not account for the fact that the East Arnhem local government area (LGA) remains one of the
10 most disadvantaged LGAs in Australia
In reaction, Ms Burney says she was "shocked at that statement".
"Yunupiŋu spent his entire life fighting for his people, fighting for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people across this country and also advocating a Voice to Parliament," she said.
"Quite frankly, Peter Dutton should apologise for taking the name of Yunupiŋu in vain.
"The idea that there isn't disadvantage in north-east Arnhem Land is patently ridiculous.
"Peter Dutton has no right at all to use the name of Yunupiŋu in that way."
NOTE: Yunupiŋu's surname and image is used as per the wishes of his family.

items.synopsis: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has continued to defy public pressure to immediately step down, by announcing he will retire next year, while the Australian share market has risen for its fifth day in a row as concerns about higher-for-longer interest rates subsided. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas board set for a shakeup as Richard Goyder becomes the latest high-profile exit, ASX rises for fifth straight day

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has risen for its fifth straight day, with the materials and industrial sectors driving the gains. The ASX 200 had risen 0.5% to 7,076 points by 10:20am AEDT. Some of today's best performing stocks include Sayona Mining (+5%), Paladin Energy (+4.2%) and Core Lithium (+4.1%). Qantas shares gained 0.8% to $4.94, after the airline said its chairman Richard Goyder would retire in one year's time — resisting public pressure for him to step down immediately. On the flip side, shares of Bank of Queensland fell 3.6%. This was after the bank reported its statutory full-year profit plunged 70 per cent to $124 million. BoQ also cut its final dividend to 21 cents per shares (down from 24 cents last year). Shares of Life360 (-2.7%), Regis Resources (-1.9%) and Magellan Financial (-1.7%) also suffered heavy losses.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX rises in morning trade, along with Qantas shares

children.content: The local share market has risen for its fifth straight day, with the materials and industrial sectors driving the gains.
The ASX 200 had risen 0.5% to 7,076 points
by 10:20am AEDT.
Some of today's best performing stocks include Sayona Mining (+5%), Paladin Energy (+4.2%) and Core Lithium (+4.1%).
Qantas shares
gained 0.8% to $4.94, after the airline said its chairman
Richard Goyder
would retire in one year's time — resisting public pressure for him to step down immediately.
On the flip side, shares of
Bank of Queensland
fell 3.6%.
This was after the bank reported its statutory full-year profit plunged 70 per cent to $124 million.
BoQ also cut its final dividend to 21 cents per shares (down from 24 cents last year).
Shares of Life360 (-2.7%), Regis Resources (-1.9%) and Magellan Financial (-1.7%) also suffered heavy losses.

props.alt: A list showing that mining stocks are making the biggest gains on the ASX 200 on 11 October.

children.content: Many of today's best performing ASX stocks are mining companies.
(Eikon)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Country Garden is likely to default on its international debts, in another major blow to the nation's struggling property sector. China's largest property developer owes debts of about $US200 billion — with nearly $US11 billion ($17b) in dollar-denominated offshore bonds. The company revealed that it had missed the deadline for a payment of $93.5 million ($HK470m) on some of its debts. In a statement to the Hong Kong stock exchange, the developer warned that of its expectations that it “will not be able to meet all of its offshore payment obligations when due or within the relevant grace periods". Country Garden also said it includes (but is not limited to) the US dollar notes that it previously issued to lenders. “Such non-payment may lead to relevant creditors of the group demanding acceleration of payment of the relevant indebtedness owed to them or pursuing enforcement action." The company faces a critical deadline next week. If Country Garden fails to pay a $23 million ($US15m) coupon by October 17 (the end of its 30-day grace period for missing a payment), it will formally be deemed to be in default.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China's biggest property developer Country Garden could default on its debt next week

children.content: Country Garden is likely to default on its international debts, in another major blow to the nation's struggling property sector.
China's largest property developer owes debts of about $US200 billion — with nearly $US11 billion ($17b) in dollar-denominated offshore bonds.
The company revealed that it had missed the deadline for a payment of $93.5 million ($HK470m) on some of its debts.

In a statement to the Hong Kong stock exchange, the developer warned that of its expectations that it “will not be able to meet all of its offshore payment obligations when due or within the relevant grace periods".
Country Garden also said it includes (but is not limited to) the US dollar notes that it previously issued to lenders.
“Such non-payment may lead to relevant creditors of the group demanding acceleration of payment of the relevant indebtedness owed to them or pursuing enforcement action."
The company faces a critical deadline next week.
If Country Garden fails to pay a $23 million ($US15m) coupon by October 17 (the end of its 30-day grace period for missing a payment), it will formally be deemed to be in default.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Outgoing Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has released a short statement after announcing his retirement from the role ahead of the airline's 2024 AGM. He said the board had recognised the "significant reputation and customer service issues" plaguing the airline, and was c ommitted to taking accountability. Here's his full statement: "As a board, we acknowledge the significant reputation and customer service issues facing the group and recognise that accountability is required to restore trust. "Qantas has gone through an incredibly difficult period since our operation was grounded during the pandemic. "The recovery has not been easy, and mistakes were made. We again apologise for those times where we got it wrong. "I have always sought to act in the best interests of Qantas. Measured and orderly succession at board level will support the important work underway led by Vanessa [Hudson] and her new management team. "Fundamentally, the group is in a very strong position to overcome its current challenges and deliver for all its stakeholders in the years ahead."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Outgoing Qantas chair Goyder says 'accountability is required to restore trust'

children.content: Outgoing Qantas chairman Richard Goyder
has released a short statement after announcing his retirement from the role ahead of the airline's 2024 AGM.
He said the board had recognised the "significant reputation and customer service issues" plaguing the airline, and was c
ommitted to taking accountability
Here's his full statement:
"As a board, we
acknowledge the significant reputation and customer service issues
facing the group and recognise that
accountability is required to restore trust
"Qantas has gone through an incredibly difficult period since our operation was grounded during the pandemic.
"The recovery has not been easy, and
mistakes were made
. We again apologise for those times where we got it wrong.
"I have always sought to act in the best interests of Qantas. Measured and
orderly succession at board level will support the important work underway led by Vanessa [Hudson]
and her new management team.
"Fundamentally, the group is in a very strong position to overcome its current challenges and deliver for all its stakeholders in the years ahead."

items.synopsis: Advocates say access to mental health services needs to be urgently improved after an ABS report reveals an increase in tragedy all too common in First Nations communities.

title.children: 'It's in your face': Shocking figures reveal leading cause of death for Indigenous children

image.altText: Canoe sitting on grass in front of sunset and lake

items.synopsis: Dozens of schools across three states are desperately trying to come up with a plan B after a popular school camp venue was unable to secure insurance to host students.

title.children: School camp tradition under threat as insurers refuse to cover venues

image.altText: Collage of a man in a polaroid frame with Vote No signage, Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Warren Mundine

items.synopsis: The biggest known donor to the Advance Australia campaign group has backed a conspiracy theorist political candidate and holds a business interest in Indigenous land ventures.

title.children: Meet Simon Fenwick, the former Wall Street investor funding the No campaign

image.altText: Man looking in mirror .

items.synopsis: The Victorian Coroner foreshadows he will be asking police to explain why officers were not wearing body cameras when they fatally shot Stanley Turvey after a three-day manhunt.

title.children: Court hears fugitive told armed police, 'I'm going to shoot you, or you're going to shoot me'

image.altText: Mustafa Barghouti

items.synopsis: A Palestinian political leader says terrorist group Hamas is ready to free civilian hostages if Israel accepts an immediate ceasefire, claiming the militants have agreed not to carry out executions.

title.children: Palestinian politician claims Hamas ready to swap hostages

items.synopsis: Satellite and drone imagery capture the aftermath of the ongoing fighting in Israel and Gaza.

title.children: These hotspots dotted across southern Israel reveal the scale of attacks

image.altText: CCTV shows 'chaotic' daylight shooting in suburban Perth

items.synopsis: A second man is charged after a video is released by police showing a series of gunshots being fired in a residential street in Perth's south.

title.children: Dramatic vision of gunfire erupting in suburban street in broad daylight released by police

image.altText: a man wearing a suit arriving at a court and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: A Federal Court judge orders the war veteran to pay a security to cover Nine Entertainment's court costs ahead of appeal against landmark defamation loss.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith ordered to pay $910k before appeal over war crimes defamation decision
